metadata.title: Asymmetric allylic substitution by chiral palladium catalysts: Which is more reactive, major π-allyl Pd(II) species or minor π-allyl species?

Asymmetric allylic substitution by chiral palladium catalysts: Which is more reactive, major π-allyl Pd(II) species or minor π-allyl species? Chisato Urano Masatoshi Onuki Yuuta Uchida Risa Suzuki Kiyoshi Sato * Dai Masui Motowo Yamaguchi Takamichi Yamagishi * Division of Applied Chemistry, Graduate School of Urban Environmental Sciences, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 1-1 Minami-ohsawa, Hachioji, Tokyo 192-0397, Japan Division of Applied Chemistry Graduate School of Urban Environmental Sciences Tokyo Metropolitan University 1-1 Minami-ohsawa Hachioji Tokyo 192-0397 Japan ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The reactivity difference of major and minor π-allyl species was examined for two typed asymmetric allylic substitutions via linear symmetrical π-allyl and linear unsymmetrical π-allyl intermediates. 31P NMR observation of the stoichiometric reaction of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π -allyl)(N-P-N-type ligand)]+ with malonate ion verified that major species was much more reactive than the minor one. In the case of the reaction of [Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP)]+ species with soft amido ion, increase in the minor/major ratio of the π-allyl species afforded higher enantioselectivity to indicate that the minor π-allyl was more reactive than the major one. Keywords Pd-catalyzed asymmetric allylic alkylation and amination N-P-N type phosphine ligand with two oxazoline units Reactivity difference of major- and minor-π-allyls species 31P NMR observation of the reaction time course 1 Introduction The asymmetric allylic substitution by chiral palladium catalyst is a good synthetic tool to construct bioactive chiral substances and many reaction systems were reported using various types of chiral ligands such as diphosphines, diamines and oxazoline derivatives, etc. [1]. In the asymmetric allylic substitution, one generally observes the formation of two intermediary π-allyl species and is apt to regard that the major species reacts faster and governs the direction of chiral induction. In the asymmetric hydrogenation of dehydroamino acids by rhodium catalysts, J. Halpern reported that, in some diphosphine systems, the less stable π-complex of dehydroamino acid (minor species) is far more reactive than the more stable π-complex (major species) to give chiral amino acid derivatives in high enantioselectivities with unexpected direction of chiral induction [2]. The clarification of the reactivity difference of the major and minor π-allyl intermediates together with identification of the structure of the π-allyl intermediates would afford important information concerning the reaction mechanism and the character of the transition state of allylic substitution reaction. As the effective asymmetric alkylation of allyl acetate compounds, T. Hayashi reported the first successful alkylation of 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate by Pd(II)-((S)-(R)-BPPFA) catalyst using acetylacetonate anion as a soft nucleophile to afford high enantioselectivity over 90 %ee [3]. The reaction proceeds via enantiotopos-selective attack of nucleophile to the symmetrical 1,3-diphneyl-π-allyl intermediate. Using α-acetaminomalonate anion, we reported the highly selective allylic alkylation by Pd(II)-(S)-BINAP catalyst (94 %ee) [4]. The structure of η3-1,3-diphenylallyl intermediates was elucidated as (syn,syn)-1,3-diphneyl-π-allyl and (syn,anti)-1,3-diphneyl-π-allyl complexes in the ratio of 92.5 : 7.5 by 1H-NMR data (3 J HH values of the terminal allyl protons) and 31P NMR [5]. However, reactivity difference was not verified because of the rapid π−σ−π conversion between major and minor intermediates in this enantiotopos-selective allylic substitution. In this paper we tried to verify the reactivity difference between major and minor π-allyl species for two reaction systems, enantiotopos-selective allylic substitution via symmetrical π-allyl intermediate and enantioface-selective allylic substitution via unsymmetrical π-allyl intermediate along with the structure elucidation of the major and minor intermediates. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Enantiotopos-selective allylic alkylation by Pd(phenylbis(2-((S)-4′-alkyl-2′oxazolinyl)phenyl)phosphine) (Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2) catalyst In the case of N-P-N type ligand with chiral two N-units, a chiral phosphorus unit will be formed if one of N-units ligates to metal selectively. We realized the selective ligation of one of chiral N-units to metal (Rh or Pd) using a phosphinediamine ligand having two chiral phenethylamine units ((S,S)-PhP(PA)2 : 1) and observed good to high enantioselectivities (up to 95 %ee) in the Rh(I)-catalyzed asymmetric hydrogenation of acrylic acid derivatives in 1996 [6]. In 1993 A. Pfaltz, G. Helmchen and J. M. J. William independently reported the chiral phosphinooxazoline ligand (PHOX) and realized good to high enantioselectivities in the Pd-catalyzed asymmetric allylic alkylation reactions [66a] and Ir(I)-catalyzed asymmetric hydrogenations [8] Fig. 1 . We prepared several novel N-P-N ligands phenylbis(2-((S)-4′-alkyl-2′-oxazolinyl)phenyl) phosphine ((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 : 2a∼2c (R = i-Pr,t-Bu and benzyl)) expecting the formation of P-chiral center by the selective ligation of one oxazolinyl unit to palladium. X-ray analysis of the single crystal of the PdCl2((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2: 2b)) complex showed the selective ligation of the ligand 2b and the formation of a phosphorus chiral center with an S P configuration [9, 10]. The 31P and 1H NMR spectra indicate that the PdCl2(2b) complex is present in solution as a sole species (Fig. 2 ) We prepared [Pd(C3H5)((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2)]Cl complexes as the catalyst and examined the effectiveness of the specific chiral field having (S p)-phosphorus atom in the allylic alkylation reaction of linear and cyclic allyl substrates and compared the results with those which were reported using Pd-(S)-PHOX catalysts. Eqs. (1)–(3) Using present phenylbis((S)-oxazolinylphenyl)phosphine ligands ((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 :2) high enantioselectivities were obtained for linear allyl substrates as shown in equations (1)∼ (2) and the reaction was (S)-selective for linear allyl compounds [10]. The %ee for 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate, the %ee obtained by Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2) was high (94 %ee (S)), though Pd((S)-PHOX) (R= t Bu) catalyst was reported to afford a superior result (98 %ee (S)) [7]. The %ee obtained for 2-acetoxy-3-pentene by Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2) was the highest one (95 %ee (S)) at that time [10], while %ee reported by Pd-((S)-PHOX) catalyst was about ca.70 %ee at most [7]. In the reaction of cyclohexen-3-yl acetate we obtained moderate %ee (45 ∼ 57 %ee (R)) using the catalyst having 2a or 2b ligand. The Pd catalyst having a (S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 ligand with a benzyl unit (2c) [11] gave a fairly good enantioselectivity (78 %ee (R)) in the same reaction (eq. 3), while Pd catalyst with PHOX ligand (R = t Bu) was reported to give a racemic product for the same substrate [12]. But very high %ee (more than 95 %ee) was reported by using a modified PHOX ligand with a cymantrene unit [13]. In the case of cyclohepten-3-yl acetate, Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2) catalyst indicated a high chiral induction ability of 86 %ee (R) [14]. We concluded that the present Pd-((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2) catalysts generally construct a specific chiral field more effective than that by Pd-(S)-PHOX catalysts except for 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate with a large steric factor. We examined the structure of linear π-allyl intermediates (1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl and 1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl species) in solution in order to discuss the chiral induction direction and the reactivity difference between two π-allyl intermediates of the PhP(Ox-R)2 ligand systems. X-ray analysis of the single crystal of [Pd (1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2)]Cl complex indicates that the complex obtained is an exo-species with a syn,syn-1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl unit and the stereogenic phosphorus atom has an S P configuration similarly as in the PdCl2((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2) case [10]. Analysis also indicates that Pd-Callyl bond trans to phosphorus atom (2.274 Å) is longer than the Pd-Callyl bond trans to nitrogen atom (2.125 Å) and this suggests the preferential attack of nucleophile onto the allyl carbon trans to the phosphorus atom to result in the (S)-product formation (Eq. 2). In the 31P NMR of Pd(1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2) in CDCl3 solution three Pd species were observed in the ratio of 72 : 6 : 22, denoted as major, minor B, minor A from the higher chemical shift (Fig. 3 ). The coupling constants of central allyl proton (Hb : dd, 3 J HH = 13.2 and 10.3 Hz) in 1H NMR of the major species clearly indicate that 1,3-Me2-π-allyl unit has the syn,syn-configuration. In the differential NOE of the major species we observed the amplification of the signal intensity of central allyl proton Hb and methyl protons of π-allyl unit, which are proximal to tert-butyl protons of the oxazolinyl unit ligating to palladium. From these data the major species in solution was concluded to be exo-π -allyl complex (Fig. 3). The coupling constants of the central proton Hb (3 J HH = 11.7 and 11.2 Hz) of the minor A species in 1H NMR indicates that π-allyl unit has the syn,syn-configuration similarly to the major species and we deduced that the minor A is the endo-π-allyl species. The larger difference of the chemical shift of Ha and Hc (Δδ =1.78 ppm) and much lower chemical shift of Hc (4.52 ppm) of the major species will support the preferential attack of the nucleophile onto the allyl carbon trans to P-Pd bond of the major π-allyl species to afford (S)-product. In the case of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S))-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2)]+, 31P NMR indicated the presence of two π-allyl species in THF solution in the ratio of 81 : 19 (Fig. 4 ). The coupling constants of the central proton Hb of the major species indicate that the 1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl unit has the syn,syn-configuration. Although we could not observe the signal of central allyl proton Hb of the minor π-allyl species, the observed direction of chiral induction in the actual alkylation reaction of 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate will support the conclusion that the major species of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S))-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2)]+ is the exo-π-allyl species. As for the Pd((S)-PHOX) complex having 1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl unit, Helmchen reported that two species, exo- and endo-species with syn,syn-π-allyl unit, are present as major and minor species in solution and they are in a rapid equilibrium by apparent allyl rotation via penta-coordinated species [15]. Our results of [Pd(1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox-tBu)2)]+ and the reports by Helmchen on the [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S))-PHOX)]+ will support the conclusion that exo- and endo-species of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S))-PhP(Ox- t Bu)2)]+ are present as major and minor species and exo-species donates (S)-product and endo-species will deliver (R)-product preferentially. In our asymmetric allylic alkylation of 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate, the ratio of (S)-product/(R)-product exceeded the ratio of major species/minor species and one may estimate that major species reacts faster than minor species. But it is difficult to exactly estimate the degree of real reactivity difference between major and minor species because of the lack of information on the enantiotopos-selectivity of the nucleophile attack on the symmetrical π-allyl unit of major and minor species. In the alkylation of 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate using Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox-tBu)2) catalyst, we observed peculiar results of asymmetric induction (Table 1 ). In polar solvent (acetonitrile), the substitution reaction generally afforded high enantiomeric excess, while in less polar solvent (THF), the enantiomeric excess was lower than that obtained in acetonitrile. In the reaction of 1,3-diphenylallyl acetate with Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox-tBu)2) catalyst, %ee in THF was largely depressed to 70 %ee (Runs 5 and 6). With Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox-iPr)2) catalyst similar tendency was observed (Runs 3 and 4). In the asymmetric reactions, lowering of the reaction temperature generally increases the %ee. In the present case the reaction at 0 °C lowered the %ee and raising the temperature to 40 °C a slight increase of %ee was observed (Runs 6∼8). The concentration of nucleophile also affected the %ee. High concentration of the nucleophile decreased the %ee, while the low concentration of the nucleophile increased the %ee. These effects of the reaction temperature and nucleophile concentration made us suspicious of the rapidness of the interconversion between exo- and endo-Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl) species in the present Pd((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 system, although the interconversion between exo- and endo-species was reported to be rapid for the case of Pd(1,3-diphneyl-π-allyl)((S)-PHOX)) [15]. It is reported that the presence of strongly solvating solvents such as acetonitrile or dimethyl sulfoxide [16] or of halide ion [17] facilitates the interconversion between exo- and endo-species by apparent rotation of the π-allyl unit via penta-coordinated complex. It is expected that in THF solution the interconversion via allyl rotation will be less activated than in acetonitrile solution. Under the conditions that the interconversion between exo- and endo-π-allyls is rather slow and that the exo-species is more reactive than endo-species, rapid catalytic cycles by high concentration of nucleophile will raise the percentage of endo-species in solution and will cause a decrease of %ee. In the case of low concentration of nucleophile, the interconversion would compete with alkylation rate and it will cause an increase of %ee. The temperature-dependent catalytic behavior seems to suggest the rate of interconversion is strongly dependent on the reaction temperature. Raising the reaction temperature will hasten the interconversion of two π-allyls to compete with the alkylation rate and will cause a slight increase of the %ee by compensating the decrease of the %ee at higher temperature. In the reaction at lower temperature, two effects compete to result in a decrease of the %ee. We examined the alkylation reaction in CH2Cl2 solution, in which the interconversion is expected to be slow as in THF. The reaction proceeded very slowly (40 % yield after 240 h reaction) but afforded relatively high %ee (run 11, Table 1). This result will correspond to the reaction with a low concentration of nucleophile: the interconversion, though slow in CH2Cl2, will compete with the very slow alkylation reaction and the higher %ee will be obtained. By 31P NMR measurement we traced the reaction time course of the stoichiometric reaction of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- i Pr)2)]+PF6 − (Pd-2a complex) with equimolar dimethyl sodiomalonate in THF at 0 °C in the absence of chloride ion and strongly solvating solvent. We used Pd-2a complex instead of Pd-2b because of the availability of 2a. At the reaction time of 0 min, the Pd-2a was observed as a mixture of the major and minor complexes similarly as Pd-2b complex. The major isomer was consumed as the reaction proceeded and the new signal appeared with higher chemical shift of 9.88 ppm which would correspond to the [Pd(0)(alkene)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- i Pr)2)] (Fig. 5 ) as reported similarly by G. Helmchen and M. Reggelin using PHOX ligand [18], while the minor complex was nearly intact under the examined conditions. These results clearly indicate that in the present Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2) system the interconversion between exo- and endo-species was slow and the major exo-π-allyl complex has higher reactivity than the minor endo-complex in THF. The rise of the ratio of endo-complex in solution lowered the %ee to 70 %ee in spite of the reactivity difference between two π-allyl species. On the other hand, in acetonitrile the interconversion was rather fast and the preferential reaction of the exo-species afforded high %ee (94 %ee) by the selective attack of nucleophile onto the allylic carbon trans to the phosphorus atom of the ligand. In the case of Pd(1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl)(PhP(Ox-tBu)2 complex, interconversion between exo- and endo-complexes was fast and we could not clarify the reactivity difference between exo- and endo-(1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl)Pd complexes by 31P NMR measurement. However, the asymmetric reaction afforded the (S)-product predominantly and the (S) / (R) product ratio (97 : 3) by far exceeded the major / minorA ratio (ca. 78 : 22) of the complex. It strongly suggests that the major species has the higher reactivity than the minor one. 2.2 Enantioface-selective allylic substitution of 1,3-dimethyl-2-buten-1-yl acetate by Pd(II)-(S)-BINAP catalyst Previously we reported the high chiral induction in the enantiotopos-selective allylic alkylation via symmetrical 1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl intermediate using Pd(II)-(S)-BINAP catalyst [4]. This time we examined the enantioface-selective allylic substitution(amination) via unsymmetrical π-allyl intermediate using Pd(II)-(S)-BINAP catalyst in order to obtain a synthetic tool to prepare chiral amino compounds with various structures. In the asymmetric allylic substitution via unsymmetrical π-allyl intermediate, it is necessary to control both the enantioface-selectivity and regioselectivity in order to lead to the effective asymmetric reaction. First we examined the regioselectivity in the amination of 2-buten-1-yl acetate and 1,3-dimethyl-2-buten-1-yl acetate using various amino compounds and diphosphine ligands (dppe, (S)-(R)-BPPFA, and (S)-BINAP). The regioselectivity in the amination of 2-buten-1-yl acetate was observed to be dependent on the electronic and steric factors of the nucleophile, but no good combination to afford selectively a product with a chiral carbon (branched product) was observed except phthalimide - (S)-(R)-BPPFA case (Scheme 1 and Table 2 ). However, the enantioselectivity obtained by BPPFA ligand was much lower (19 %ee) than that by BINAP ligand (30 %ee). On the other hand, reaction of 1,3-dimethyl-2-buten-1-yl acetate with N-methyl-p-tosylamide gave a product with a chiral carbon (branched A) very selectively for three phosphine ligands. In this case, the steric factor of 1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl species is considered to govern the regioselectivity. As shown in Fig. 6 , [Pd(1-methyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP)]+ species is present as a mixture of four components in the ratio of 4 : 81 : trace : 15 in solution to suggest that the regioselectivity to produce a chiral carbon will be low, while [Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP)]+ species was present as 2 components, largely deviated to the major species (major / minor = 97 / 3) in CDCl3. The chemical shift difference of two phosphine units of the major species of [Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP)]+ in solution is larger than that of [Pd(1-methyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP)]+. It will suggest that the difference in the electronic character of two allylic carbons of the 1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl species is larger than that of 1-methyl-π-allyl species and it will cause high regioselectivity. It is also to be noted that the 31P chemical shift difference of the minor species of [Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)(S)-BINAP)]+ is larger than that of the major species. It suggests that the difference of electronic character of two allyl carbons of the minor species is larger that of the major species. The asymmetric reaction of 1,3-dimethyl-2-butenyl acetate with N-methyl-p-tosylamide in THF using Pd-(S)-BINAP catalyst proceeded slowly and afforded fairly high %ee (higher than 80 %ee), while the reaction with Pd-(S)-(R)-BPPFA proceeded fairly rapidly but the enantioselectivity was low (ca. 30 %ee) [18]. The absolute configuration of the dominant enantiomer by Pd-(S)-(R)-BPPFA was determined to be (S) as shown in Scheme 2 : amination product was derivatized via oxidation and esterification [19] to N-methyl-N-tosylalanine methyl ester and its sign of optical rotation was compared with that derived from authentic (S)-N-methylalanine. The HPLC analysis with a chiral Eq. (4) column(Chiralcel OB-h, hexane/2-propanol(99/1)) of the amination products obtained by Pd((S)-BINAP) and Pd((S)-(R)-BPPFA) indicated that the dominant enantiomer by Pd((S)-BINAP) has the (R)-absolute configuration based on the difference of the retention time (Eq. 4). The possible structures of Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP) complex are indicated with the stability difference estimated by MM2 calculation [20] in Fig.7 . Because of the C 2-symmetry of BINAP ligand only four species are to be considered. Among four π-allyl species, calculation suggests that species C (Me2, anti) and D(anti, Me2) are much less stable than species A and B because of the presence of two anti-methyl units in the π-allyl structure. In the measurement of 1H and 31P NMR of Pd(1,3-dimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP), we observed two π-allyl species of (syn, syn)-structure(major) and of (syn,anti or anti,syn)-structure(minor) in the ratio of 76 : 24 in CDCl3 solution. This result will support the above classification. In the 1H NMR of the major species of Pd(1,1,3-Me3-π-allyl) in CDCl3, central allyl proton was observed as doublet with a coupling constant of 12 Hz at 5.31 ppm and it suggests that the major species will be the isomer A or isomer B, where the former affords (S)-product and the latter will deliver (R)-product by the attack of amido nucleophile. As for minor species the central allyl proton was not observed because of probable overlapping of signals in the 1H NMR measurement. The amination reaction via [Pd(1,1,3-Me3-allyl)((S)-BINAP)] species afforded the (R)-product in high enantioselectivity, however it is difficult to determine that the isomer B is major species or minor species based on the MM2 calculation only. Another information is necessary to conclude which species, major or minor species, governs the direction of chiral induction in the present system. The present allylic amination reaction by Pd-(S)-BINAP catalyst showed an interesting solvent effect using various relatively less polar solvents. The ratio of major to minor π-allyl species estimated by 31P NMR showed a variation from 97 / 3 to 83 / 17 and the (R)-selectivity increased from ca. 50 %ee to 92 %ee as the ratio of the minor species increased including THF-DMSO case (Table 3 ). This strongly suggests that the minor species B reacts faster than the major one A to govern the chiral induction under the rapid interconversion between major and minor π-allyls through π−σ−π conversion. Therefore, we conclude that, in the present enantioface-selective amination, two allyl complexes A and B are present in solution and the minor π-allyl species B is much more reactive to induce the (R)-selectivity exceeding the reaction of the major π-allyl species A which induces the (S)-selectivity. We estimated the reactivity difference based on the minor species / major species ratio and the (R) / (S) ratio. In less polar solvents, the reactivity of minor species was 80∼120 fold larger than that of major species, while in THF-DMSO the minor species reacted about 250 fold faster than the major species. This specific effect of DMSO may be explained by the increase of the difference in electronic character of two allyl carbons of π-allyl unit in polar solvent observed as the increase of the chemical shift difference of two phosphine units. The second factor is the activation of the sodio-p-tosylamide by the solvation of sodium ion by DMSO molecule to donate the naked anion character to the amido ion. 3 Conclusion Using (S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 and (S)-BINAP ligands, the reactivity difference between major Pd(π-allyl) intermediate and minor Pd((π-allyl) species in enantiotopos-selective or enantioface-selective allylic substitution reaction was examined. The combination of the chiral ligand, structure of the substrate and character of the nucleophile largely affected the difference of reactivities between major and minor π-allyl intermediates. In the case of N-P-N typed (S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 system, the selective ligation of one oxazoline unit induced the stereogenic phosphorus of S p configuration and a much higher reactivity of the major species (exo-isomer) was verified experimentally by observing the time-course of the reaction between [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2)]+ species and dimethyl malonate ion by 31P NMR spectroscopy under the conditions of slow interconversion between exo- and endo-species in THF. In the enantioface-selective allylic amination of 1,1,3-trimethylallyl acetate by Pd-((S)-BINAP) catalyst, the minor π-allyl species of Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP) was concluded to afford a dominant (R)-enantiomer based on the relationship between the minor/major ratio and the enantioselectivity contrary to our first expectations. The elucidation of π-allyl intermediate structures and the determination of the reactivity difference between major and minor π-allyl species would afford important information of the transition state of the substitution reaction. Further examination is needed to fully elucidate the reaction mechanism. 4 Experimental and note a. Preparation of (S,S)-bis(oxazolinylphenyl)phenylphosphine) (S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 (S,S)-PhP(Ox-R)2 (R= i-Pr, t-Bu, or benzyl) ligands were prepared by the reaction of lithiated 4-alkyl-2-phenyl-4,5-dihydrooxazole with dichlorophenylphosphine and the product was purified by column chromatography using an eluent of either hexane - ethyl acetate or hexane - diethyl ether mixture. b. Typical allylic substitution procedure: In a Schlenk tube were placed [Pd(C3H5)(chiral ligand)Cl] (or [Pd(C3H5)(chiral ligand)PF6]) (0.01 mmol), 1,3-diphenyl-2-propenyl acetate (1 mmol), and a 5 mL solvent (THF, or CH3CN) under nitrogen. To this mixture was added dimethyl sodiomalonate (1 mmol) solution in THF or CH3CN (5 mL), which was prepared in an another Schlenk tube, via a stainless cannula. The mixture was stirred at 25 °C for 48 h under nitrogen. In the case of asymmetric amination of 4-methyl-3-penten-2-yl acetate the ratio of substrate / nucleophile / Pd catalyst was 50 / 50 / 1 in THF. The amination was continued at 25 °C for 40 h. The reaction product was separated using a short silica gel column. The enantioselectivity of the product was determined by HPLC using a chiral column (Chiralcel OB-H) or by NMR measurement using a chiral shift reagent (Eu(hfc)3) in dry benzene-d6. c. Preparation of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)(PhP(Ox-iPr)2)]PF6 complex After overnight reaction of di-μ-chlorobis(π-allyl)dipalladium with equimolar (S,S)-PhP(Ox-iPr)2 in CHCl3, methanol solution of 3-fold amount of NH4PF6 was added and the mixture was stirred for 2.5 h. After washing the solution with water, the solution was evaporated in vacuo to give pale yellow solid. This solid was purified by reprecipitation(CHCl3-Et2O) and recrystallization(CHCl3-hexane) to afford [Pd(C3H5)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- i Pr)2)]PF6 as white solid (85 % yield). [Pd(C3H5)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- i Pr)2)]PF6 (0.09 mmole) was converted to 1,3-diphneylallyl complex by the allylic alkylation in the presence of 5-fold molar 1,3-diphenylpropenyl acetate and 3-fold dimethyl sodiomalonate in THF for 48 h. The complex was extracted with CH2Cl2 after the addition of NH4PF6 methanol solution. Dichloromethane solution was washed with water and evaporated to dryness in vacuo to result in yellow oil. The oil was purified by recrystallization from hexane - ethyl acetate to afford [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- i Pr)2)]PF6 as yellow solid (71 % yield). Spectral data: 31P NMR(CDCl3) 22.03 ppm(exo), 28.62(endo). FAB MS: m/z = 783 (M-PF6)+. d. Estimation of the reaction rate difference in the stoichiometric reaction of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)(PhP(Ox-iPr)2)]PF6 with equimolar dimethyl sodiomalonate in THF by 31P NMR measurement Dimethyl sodiomalonate in THF was added at -60 °C to the THF solution of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π-allyl)((S,S)-PhP(Ox- i Pr)2)]PF6 complex in an NMR tube and the temperature of the mixture was raised to -40 °C and the 31P NMR signal was measured as the data at the time 0. Then the temperature was raised to 0 °C and after the reaction for 1 min the temperature was rapidly lowered to -40 °C and the 31P NMR signal was measured as the data at the time of 1 min. then, the cycle of the reaction at 0 °C and measurement of 31P NMR signal at -40 °C was repeated. Credit author statement I, Takamichi Yamagishi, corresponding author of the manuscript “Asymmetric Allylic Substitution by Chiral Palladium Catalysts: Which is more reactive, major π-allyl Pd(II) species or minor π-allyl species?” (MOLCAA-d-2−00726) revised the manuscript to in order to correspond to the comments by reviewers. I want to submit our revised manuscript to be reviewed again. Declaration of Competing Interest As the supervisor of the research project and the corresponding author of the present article, I declare that all members have no interests to declare. Acknowledgement We are indebted to the financial support (Grant-in-Aid for Special Research Project) for the present research from the Tokyo Metropolitan University. References [1] a) G. coredata.dc:description: The reactivity difference of major and minor π-allyl species was examined for two typed asymmetric allylic substitutions via linear symmetrical π-allyl and linear unsymmetrical π-allyl intermediates. 31P NMR observation of the stoichiometric reaction of [Pd(1,3-diphenyl-π -allyl)(N-P-N-type ligand)]+ with malonate ion verified that major species was much more reactive than the minor one. In the case of the reaction of [Pd(1,1,3-trimethyl-π-allyl)((S)-BINAP)]+ species with soft amido ion, increase in the minor/major ratio of the π-allyl species afforded higher enantioselectivity to indicate that the minor π-allyl was more reactive than the major one.
coredata.dc:title: Asymmetric allylic substitution by chiral palladium catalysts: Which is more reactive, major π-allyl Pd(II) species or minor π-allyl species?

dcterms:subject.$: Pd-catalyzed asymmetric allylic alkylation and amination
